title: Aloysia wrightii
text: Aloysia wrightii is a species of flowering plant in the <a href="Verbenaceae">verbena family</a> known by the common names Wright's beebrush and oreganillo. It is native to the Sonoran Desert of <a href="southwestern%20United%20States">southwestern United States</a> and northern <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>, where it can be found in moist desert canyons, scrub, and woodland habitat. This is a thickly branching <a href="shrub">shrub</a> which reaches nearly two meters in maximum height and is generally rounded in form. It has small, oval-shaped to nearly round leaves each no more than two centimeters long. The leaves have lightly toothed edges and hairy undersides. The <a href="inflorescence">inflorescence</a> is a narrow, woolly spike up to 6 centimeters long, with small, widely spaced white flowers. It is a valuable nectar source for native solitary bees. It is also larval and adult food plant for the rustic sphinx moth "(<a href="Manduca%20rustica">Manduca rustica</a>)".
